review.title: Exploiting Social Tags for Cross-Domain Collaborative Filtering
review.abstract: One of the most challenging problems in recommender systems based on the collaborative filtering (CF) concept is data sparseness, i.e., limited user preference data is available for making recommendations. Cross-domain collaborative filtering (CDCF) has been studied as an effective mechanism to alleviate data sparseness of one domain by transferring knowledge about user preferences from other domains. However, there are two key issues that need to be addressed to make a CDCF approach successful: (a) what common characteristics can be used to establish a link between different domains and (b) how to get each domain effectively and efficiently benefit from such a link. In this paper, we propose a novel algorithm, Generalized Tag-induced Cross-domain Collaborative Filtering (GTagCDCF), that exploits user-contributed tags as common characteristics to link different domains together. Formulated from the probabilistic point of view, GTagCDCF takes into account all the user-item relations, the user-tag relations and the item-tag relations from different domains, in which the common tags take the role of effectively transferring the knowledge between different domains. Using publicly available datasets to represent three cross-domain cases, we experimentally demonstrate that GTagCDCF substantially outperforms several state-of-the-art single domain and cross-domain CF-based recommendation approaches. GTagCDCF is also shown to be effective for heterogeneous cross-domain cases, in which different domains are characterized by different types of user preferences. In addition, our investigation of the impact of user tagging behavior on GTagCDCF led to the conclusion that users can already benefit from GTagCDCF if they only share a few common tags. Finally, we validate the robustness of GTagCDCF with respect to the scale of datasets and the number of domains, based on a three-domain experiment.

Cross-domain collaborative filtering (CDCF) has been studied as an effective mechanism to linds sparseness of one domain using the knowledge about user preferences from other domains. A key question that needs to be answered in the context of CDCF is what common features can be used to link effective knowledge transfer.

sections.heading: 2.3. Tag-aware Recommendation
sections.text: The work presented in this paper also relates to a general category of CF approaches, which we call tag awareness recommendation, where tags are used to improve recommendations in various ways, e.g. by integrating tags into traditional user-based CF and item-based CF [Liang et al. 2010; Sen et al. 2009; Tso-Sutter et al. 2008], by integrating tags into a probabilistic latent semantic model [Hofmann 2004], in order to unify user-item relationships and item-tag relationships [Wang et al. 2006; Wetzker et al. 2009], and by using tag-based user correlations as a regulation for PMF [Zhen et al. 2009]. More recently, another group of modern approaches has recommended tensor factoring techniques [Kolda et al. 2006; Sun et al. 2009] for tag awareness recommendation. [Zhen et al. 2009] Under such approaches, syllables {item-tag recommendations or item-meal recommendations from Sun] are used for day-meal recommendations.

sections.heading: 4. DESCRPTION OF THE GTAGCDCF APPROACH
sections.text: First, we present the model and learning algorithm underlying our GTagCDCF approach, showing how tags bridge different domains, and then we present a complexity analysis of GTagCDCF and a compact formulation of this model that could be useful to practitioners.

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section, we report on the experiments we have conducted to evaluate the proposed GTagCDCF approach, by which we evaluate the benefits of social tags as effective bridges between domains that facilitate CDCF. We begin with a detailed description of the datasets used in our experiments and explain the setup of the experiment, followed by an analysis of the influence of the trade-off parameters α and β, which influence the relative contributions of cross-domain user-tag relationships and cross-domain item-tag relationships on the performance of GTagCDCF. We use this analysis to optimize the parameter setting of the GTagCDCF algorithm. The rest of the experiments will then be performed using the optimized algorithm. We organize the presentation of the results of these experiments to answer the following research questions: (1) Is the proposed GTagCDCF effective in improving recommendation performance in different domains? (2) How does GTagCF versus the representative number of CDF approaches involved in the CDF? (How does the CDF number affect the CDF)

sections.heading: 5.3. Impact of Tradeoff Parameters
sections.text: The compromise parameters α and β in the proposed GTagCDCF algorithm influence the relative β contributions from the cross-domain user-tag relationships and the cross-domain item-tag relationships. By using the validation determined along with the training in P1 and P2, we investigate the impact of the compromise parameters on GTagCDCF by varying their values and measuring the recommendation performance for MAE values on ML1, LT and ML2 records and MAP on LF records. Note that in the experiments reported in this section, we set the state of UPL = 5 for users in the validation group, while the recommendation performance is reported on LF records according to the holdout set of ratings or implicit feedback. We first set β = 0 in Equation (1) and examine the effects of α as shown in Figure 2 and Figure F domain.

sections.text: In the second set of our experiments, we examine the effectiveness of GTagCDCF, i.e. the effects of minimizing objective function in equivalent (1) on improving recommendation performance in various areas. Note that these experiments are also based on the validation rates under condition UPL = 5 and that the target parameters are adopted with the optimal values for P1 and P2, respectively, as observed in the previous section. sections.heading: 5.5. Performance Comparison in the Two-domain Case
sections.text: In this section, we compare the performance of the proposed GTagCDCF with a number of alternative recommendations listed below. As mentioned in Section 5.2, performance is calculated on the basis of the test set with 10 randomly separated folds. Compromise parameters are the optimal ones determined using the procedures specified in Section 5.3, i.e., α = 0.1 for ML1 and LT in P1, and α = 1, β = 1 for ML2 and LF in P2. - UBCF: User-based Collaborative Filtering [Herlocker et al. 1999] is used as a representative of the memory-based CF approaches. Neighbourhood size is matched to validation sets at 50 according to our observation of their performance. - PMF: Probabilistic Matrix Factorization [Salakhutdinov and Mnih 2008] is a state of model-based CF approach.

sections.heading: 5.6. Performance Comparison in the Three-domain Case
sections.text: As mentioned in Section 5.2, we evaluate the robustness of GTagCDCF for larger datasets and use cases with more than two domains, as described in Section 5.2. The compromise parameters are adjusted to α = 10 and β = 1, based on the performance measured on the randomly selected fold, as described in Section 5.2. Then, the performance of GTagCDCF is measured via 4-fold cross-validation. Due to the relatively large size of the datasets involved, some baselines used in the two-sided case, as in the previous subsection, are too computationally expensive to deploy, such as UBCF and TagCDCF. Furthermore, the baselines CBT and RMGM in the previous subsection are not designed for use cases with more than two domains.

Tagging has become a ubiquitous function in most modern recommender systems [Robu et al. 2009; Song et al. 2011], allowing users to annotate an item with an arbitrary textual expression in parallel to adding the ratings.

GTagCDCF builds on the widely adopted concept of collective matrix factorization (CMF) [Singh and Gordon 2008].
CF approaches are usually categorized as either memory-based or model-based [Adomavicius and Tuzhilin 2005; Breese et al. 1998; Herlocker et al. 2004].

CF approaches are usually categorized as either memory-based or model-based [Adomavicius and Tuzhilin 2005; Breese et al. 1998; Herlocker et al. 2004].
A recent overview of CF approaches can be found in [Ekstrand et al. 2011].

Depending on whether the recommendation for a user is aggregated from other users with similar interests, or from items that are similar to those for which the user already expressed a preference, memory-based CF approaches can be further categorized as either userbased collaborative filtering (UBCF) [Herlocker et al. 1999; Resnick et al. 1994] or item-based collaborative filtering [Deshpande and Karypis 2004; Linden et al.

integration [Umyarov and Tuzhilin 2011], the key drawback remains in the expensive computation for similarities among all users or items, which could hardly scale with the extremely large numbers of users and items in real-world recommender systems.
Conventional model-based CF approaches include Gaussian mixture model [Kleinberg and Sandler 2004; Si and Jin 2003] and latent semantic model [Hofmann 2004].
Conventional model-based CF approaches include Gaussian mixture model [Kleinberg and Sandler 2004; Si and Jin 2003] and latent semantic model [Hofmann 2004].

Recently, matrix factorization (MF) techniques have attracted much research attention, due to the advantages of scalability and accuracy, especially for large-scale data, as exemplified by the Netflix contest [Koren et al. 2009; Paterek 2007; Salakhutdinov and Mnih 2008].

Probabilistic matrix factorization (PMF) [Salakhutdinov and Mnih 2008] illustrates the rating factorization from a probabilistic point of view.

In addition, researchers have also proposed to model MF with multiple matrices from probabilistic point of view by extending the PMF framework with additional priors [Adams et al. 2010; Porteous et al. 2010].

In addition, researchers have also proposed to model MF with multiple matrices from probabilistic point of view by extending the PMF framework with additional priors [Adams et al. 2010; Porteous et al. 2010].

To the best of our knowledge, under the context of CF, collective matrix factorization (CMF) [Singh and Gordon 2008] is the first work that proposed to factorize multiple matrices related to either users or items in addition to user-item rating matrix.

Recently, research on CDCF has been influenced by and benefited from the progress of transfer learning [Pan and Yang 2010], a machine learning paradigm for sharing knowledge among different domains.

Coordinate system transfer [Pan et al. 2010] is proposed to first learn latent features of users and items from an auxiliary domain (which has relatively more user preference data) and then adapt them to a target domain (which has relatively less user preference data) in order to regularize the learning of latent features for the users and the items in the target domain.
Further extension has also been proposed to exploit implicit user feedback, rather than explicit user ratings, to constitute the auxiliary domain [Pan et al. 2011].
Another recent contribution exploited the explicit links derived from users’ online social network for CDCF [Shapira et al. 2013].
Similarly, multi-domain CF [Zhang et al. 2010] [Tang et al.

The implementation of SVD++ in our experiments is based on the publicly available software MyMediaLite9 [Gantner et al. 2011].

Compared to related work [Li et al. 2009a; Li et al. 2009b; Pan et al. 2010; Pan et al. 2011], in which implicit correlations are mined from user preference data, our experiments indicate that relying on explicit links could be not only more effective for improving CDCF, but could also make CDCF applicable to a wider range of use cases, for instance where the items or users in different domains are not related to each other or when different rating mechanisms are used across domains.

Compared to related work [Li et al. 2009a; Li et al. 2009b; Pan et al. 2010; Pan et al. 2011], in which implicit correlations are mined from user preference data, our experiments indicate that relying on explicit links could be not only more effective for improving CDCF, but could also make CDCF applicable to a wider range of use cases, for instance where the items or users in different domains are not related to each other or when different rating mechanisms are used across domains.
We also show that GTagCDCF outperforms our previously proposed TagCDCF approach [Shi et al. 2011].

metadata.abstractText: One of the most challenging problems in recommender systems based on the collaborative filtering (CF) concept is data sparseness, i.e., limited user preference data is available for making recommendations. Cross-domain collaborative filtering (CDCF) has been studied as an effective mechanism to alleviate data sparseness of one domain using the knowledge about user preferences from other domains. A key question to be answered in the context of CDCF is what common characteristics can be deployed to link different domains for effective knowledge transfer. In this paper, we assess the usefulness of user-contributed (social) tags in this respect. We do so by means of the Generalized Tag-induced Cross-domain Collaborative Filtering (GTagCDCF) approach that we propose in this paper and that we developed based on the general collective matrix factorization framework. Assessment is done by a series of experiments, using publicly available CF datasets that represent three cross-domain cases, i.e., two two-domain cases and one three-domain case. A comparative analysis on two-domain cases involving GTagCDCF and several state-of-the-art CDCF approaches indicates the increased benefit of using social tags as representatives of explicit links between domains for CDCF as compared to the implicit links deployed by the existing CDCF methods. In addition, we show that users from different domains can already benefit from GTagCDCF if they only share a few common tags. Finally, we use the three-domain case to validate the robustness of GTagCDCF with respect to the scale of datasets and the varying number of domains.
